newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Singapore copper premiums rise on Chinesew demand.
newsitem.headline: Singapore copper premiums rise on Chinesew demand.

text.p: Singapore copper premiums firmed this week after previous low prices triggered fresh demand while a strike at a Chilean copper mine sparked little interest, industry sources said on Friday.
Premiums over London Metal Exchange (LME) cash prices rose to around $100 a tonne from last week's $80, they said.
"The cash prices have firmed up by $25-$30 per tonne on back of techinals and good demand from the region," said a U.S trader.
Traders cited increased copper demand from Malaysia, on a pick-up in the cable and wire production industry, and better sales in Indonesia.
"There is just a lack of supplies in the region," one Japanese trader said. "I have received a lot of inquiries recently but I have no availability to offer."
The U.S trader also attributed the rise in premiums to good demand from China.
He said Chinese buying interest emerged when LME three-month copper fell to $1,900 a tonne. Prices have since recovered to be indicated around $1,960 in early London trade on Friday.
But traders said the pick-up in copper prices may curb Chinese demand in the short term.
On Thursday, industry sources said that copper stored in Shanghai warehouses, which has baffled the market over its ownership, has been offered in small lots to European metal trading houses.
The copper was being offered at a high premium in order to set a benchmark price for its eventual sale to China's strategic stockpile, one Chinese trader said.

A European trader in Beijing said he had been offered copper by the China National Non-ferrous Metals Import and Export Corp (CNIEC) at around $2,100 a tonne -- a level reflecting the London Metal Exchange (LME) cash price plus a premium of $130.
CNIEC has previously declined to comment on the reports.
Traders said a stike at Chilean state mining company Codelco's Salvador copper mine had been largely discounted.
They said the strike had little bearing on the market as the mine was considered to be small and there was reasonable availability in the wider world market.

There was also a slight firming in Singapore aluminium premiums this week reflecting fresh buying interest when prices slipped to a low in mid-week, traders said. The market's fundamentals are considered steady to firm, said the U.S trader.
The Asian zinc market remained buoyant as it continued to garner support from a firm U.S market, traders said.
They said with Southeast Asian demand growing at five percent a year and production stagnant, regional zinc prices were expected to be supported for the rest of the year.
